body: Two years after a 25-year-old woman vanished after leaving a nightclub in Manhattan, the man who has long been considered by investigators to be the main suspect in the case has been indicted on murder charges, the authorities announced on Wednesday. A grand jury in Goshen, N.Y., has indicted the suspect, Michael Mele, 25, on two counts of
title: Sex Offender Is Indicted In Killing Two Years Ago

body: Gusting wind and rain knocked out power, soaked pedestrians, delayed travelers and felled a 50-foot fully decorated Christmas tree at the South Street Seaport on Wednesday. ''The tree literally snapped,'' said John Reilly, a spokesman for the seaport. Its concrete and metal base remained upright, but the tree, a Norway spruce decked out with red
title: Storm Snarls Commutes and Topples Big Christmas Tree

body: LAST Thursday, Adam Kopels walked into Torrisi Italian Specialties in NoLIta, opened his messenger bag and pulled out Ziploc bags filled with wild greens he had gathered on the North Fork of Long Island, near where he lives. Mario Carbone, one of the restaurant's chefs and owners, sat with Mr. Kopels and sorted through clumps of baby peppercress
title: What Weed? That's Dinner

body: Oliver Tracy showed up for his first-grade portrait with a crisp white shirt tucked into navy slacks, a striped tie slightly too long for his tiny frame, and not a lock of his sun-streaked blond hair out of place. But just above Oliver's right cheek was a scab; he had tumbled while playing tag. His father, Jahn Tracy, had e-mailed the school, the
title: School Days Without Cuts or Cowlicks? Only in Pictures

body: On Thursday morning, Luis Crossman, 61, slipped his still-lean, 61-year-old body into a faded green jumpsuit and zipped it up. He pulled on his black army boots and put on his aviator shades and black cowboy hat. He tied a kerchief around his neck. ''Happy Veterans Day,'' he said, giving a tight salute, stiffening his spine and snapping together
title: Spirit of Camaraderie Persists at a Shelter for Veterans

author: E-mail: geovec@nytimes.com
body: The torch is passed, one way or the other. On the day that one champion retired and another champion could not quite repeat, a new champion won the first marathon he ever ran. At the same time, a future marathon contender was courted with a front-row seat for his first New York City Marathon. It is a wonderful seat, the back of a support truck,
title: SPORTS OF THE TIMES; Best Way to Recruit a Runner? Take Him for a Ride

body: Experiences along the New York City Marathon's 26.2-mile route were as diverse as the 45,350 official entrants who ran it Sunday. For some, the morning of the marathon was a time of uncertainty. Erwin Franieck rode the downtown R train in Brooklyn at 8:30 a.m. in sneakers and shorts -- out of place among the parkas and scarves in the car. Franieck,
title: Along the Route, a Variety Of Music and Messages

body: THE LAMBS CLUB 132 West 44th Street (Broadway), (212) 997-5262; thelambsclub.com. A clubbish and warm restaurant in the lobby of the Chatwal Hotel, the Lambs Club is a kind of Sardi's for the modern age set amid the trappings of a past one, with a gas fireplace, black paneled walls and red leather banquettes. There are fabulous if expensive
title: RECENTLY REVIEWED

body: IN late September, during the final days of the weeklong holiday of Sukkot, young boys in white shirts and black hats could often be seen lining the streets of Borough Park, a large neighborhood in southwest Brooklyn. Standing behind folding card tables arrayed with long, thin willow branches to be waved in synagogue, they called out in Yiddish,
title: LIVING IN | BOROUGH PARK, BROOKLYN; Where Ritual Sets the Rhythm

body: IT is a rare dish that transports you to not only another place, but also another time. Such is Bab al Yemen's aseed ($13), which dates to the 10th century. It is described as a dumpling. And a porridge. It can't be both, you reason, and then it arrives at your table: a dune of gray alluvium, slumping into a murky broth. How to attack this monolith
title: $25 AND UNDER; Time Travel That Comes With a Meal

body: THOMAS HAZAZ wanted out. Lying on a gurney, his chest covered with heart sensors, Mr. Hazaz was trying to cajole doctors in the emergency room at Maimonides Medical Center in Brooklyn to unplug him. In less than 24 hours, he needed to be in a tuxedo, walking his youngest daughter down the aisle in a Staten Island banquet hall. Mr. Hazaz, 52, a
title: Life and Death, Stat

body: Tholfikar Altaie, a 28-year-old Iraqi refugee who lives with his family in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, does not always know how to begin explaining to friends in New York the life he left behind in Baghdad. Their curiosity is as vast as the gaps in their knowledge. ''They think it is all camels and desert,'' Mr. Altaie said. ''I've never seen a camel in
title: BIG CITY; A Show About Iraqi Refugees, to an Audience That Can Relate

body: Former Representative Rick A. Lazio withdrew from the New York governor's race on Monday, clearing the way for the Republican nominee, Carl P. Paladino, to bolster his surprisingly aggressive candidacy with the added ballot line of the state Conservative Party. At a news conference in Midtown Manhattan, Mr. Lazio -- who had been the Conservative
title: Lazio Leaves Race, Giving Reluctant Aid to a Rival

body: 'THE MAGIC ORANGE TREE' CELEBRATION When Diane Wolkstein listened to news reports after the January earthquake in Haiti, she continually heard references to that country's extreme poverty. She found the descriptions heartbreaking, she said, because in her view Haiti has at least one source of great wealth. ''It's not poor in culture,'' said Ms.
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: Six years ago, Edward Conlon, a New York City police officer who had been writing about his beat under a pseudonym for The New Yorker, published an acclaimed memoir about his experiences in law enforcement called ''Blue Blood.'' Mr. Conlon comes from a long line of cops and joined the family profession even though he had gone to Harvard. On Friday,
title: TELEVISION REVIEW | 'BLUE BLOODS'; The Thin Family Line: A Dynasty of City Cops

body: A brief but fierce storm roared through New York City on Thursday evening, throwing down trees like sticks, crippling debris-strewn neighborhoods in Brooklyn, Queens and Staten Island, disrupting commuter rail service and killing at least one person. The storm and its aftereffects bore many of the hallmarks of a tornado, with the tops of countless
title: Wide Damage As Storm Races Across the City

body: 'CAT: THE OPERA-MUSICAL' A cat nestles just as neatly inside numerous English words -- categorical, catamaran, concatenation -- as it does on many a sofa and armchair across America. Few probably think about that, but George Plimpton did. His musings will gain new life on Sunday when Family Opera Initiative presents the premiere of ''Cat: The
title: Spare Times: For Children

body: Film Mike Hale When Lionel Rogosin's ''ON THE BOWERY'' (1956) played at Anthology Film Archives a few years back, Manohla Dargis of The New York Times called it ''a classic of its kind and a must-see for anyone who cherishes the old soul of New York.'' If you missed the film -- a combination of documentary and improvised morality tale shot on
title: THE WEEK AHEAD | SEPT. 12--SEPT. 18

body: Back in the 1950s and '60s, New York City was studded with Chock Full o'Nutscoffee shops, homegrown institutions where the budget-minded could sidle up to the lunch counter for a freshly prepared meal. But the restaurants -- once nearly as ubiquitous as the Checker cabs that inspired their yellow-and-black decor -- were all but gone by the early
title: Classic Coffee Shop Returns. But Is That Salmon on the Menu?

body: TWENTY years ago, when Fifth Avenue in Park Slope could still be called marginal in the pages of The New York Times, Michael Ayoub opened Cucina there, on the corner of Carroll Street. The restaurant was an elegantly casual Italian trattoria that managed to charm both a burgeoning population of young brownstoners with jobs in Manhattan and the
title: RESTAURANT REVIEW; Who Needs the Gastrotourists?

body: Two-thirds of New York City residents want a planned Muslim community center and mosque to be relocated to a less controversial site farther away from ground zero in Lower Manhattan, including many who describe themselves as supporters of the project, according to a New York Times poll. The poll indicates that support for the 13-story complex,
title: New York Poll Finds Wariness for Muslim Site

body: DAN WOHL met Marisa Wallace on the job at the Barnes & Noble bookstore in Brooklyn Heights. She was hired to work with him in the children's department, and he was happy to show her the ropes. Two years ago, when they decided to find a place together, he was sharing an apartment with friends in Greenpoint and she was living with her family in
title: THE HUNT; An Affordable Apartment for One

body: RESIDENTS of East 94th Street, between Lexington and Third Avenues, never expected to see a private driveway among the row of tidy brownstones on the north side of their block. But earlier this year, they discovered that the owners of No. 161, Andreas Gruson and Maria Negrete-Gruson, had built a nine-foot-wide driveway leading to their new one-car
title: Yikes! It's a Garage

body: Q.In Verdi Park, at Broadway and 72nd Street, if you follow the statue of Verdi's gaze about 20 feet upward into the trees in front of it, you will spot a large fake owl perched on a branch. Who put it there and why? It's very amusing. A. It is, isn't it? Especially to the pigeons it was supposed to scare away, as they can sometimes be seen
title: F.Y.I.; The Birds Are Laughing

body: BAY RIDGE TOWN HOUSE $879,000 BROOKLYN: 453 76th Street (between Fourth and Fifth Avenues) A three-bedroom two-bath 1925 house with living and dining rooms, a breakfast room, a deck, a patio and an English basement with a laundry room and another bedroom and bath. Sarah Parsons, Halstead (917) 748-8067; www.halstead.com TAXES: $3,563 a year PROS:
title: ON THE MARKET

body: Few New Yorkers experienced the heat wave the way Robert Najdek did: out on a blistering street in Flushing, Queens, from 7 a.m. to 3:30 p.m. daily, tearing up the old roadway so that a new one can replace it, in triple-digit temperatures that shattered meteorological records. Mr. Najdek, a highway repair supervisor for the city's Department of
title: City Savors a High of 89 As a 4-Day Heat Wave Ends

body: THE BATHING SUIT STAND at Astoria Pool sells goggles for $4 and towels for $10. But the big sellers are padlocks ($7), which are required for admission to all city pools, which opened on Tuesday for the season, so that swimmers can secure their belongings in lockers. ''Locks are our best-selling item because people show up without realizing that
title: OPEN & SHUT; Chronicle of a Changing City

body: BENEATH a floating dock off Governors Island, tucked behind the squat octagonal white ventilation tower for the Brooklyn-Battery Tunnel, there are oysters growing in New York Harbor. And not just any oysters. These little bivalves, 500,000 strong, make up the largest concentrated oyster population that the harbor has seen in perhaps a century. On a
title: Nurturing New York's Oysters

body: AS an owner of Kleinfeld, the largest designer wedding gown store in the country, Ronald Rothstein surely knows how to seduce a bride. Each of the 8,000 dresses sold in his store every year (prices, $4,500 and up) requires many hours of fittings and considerable reassurances over multiple visits, and so Mr. Rothstein (''Ronnie,'' to anyone with an
title: FRONT ROW; For That Other One In the Photo

author: E-mail: fyi@nytimes.com
body: Q.The Tony Awards will be held next Sunday. So who was Tony? A. Broadway's major honors are formally the Antoinette Perry Awards, given since 1947 for distinguished achievement in the theater. They were founded by the American Theater Wing. Ms. Perry, right, was an actress who turned to directing after she was partly paralyzed by a stroke. At the
title: F.Y.I.; The Antoinette Awards

body: THEY carry home-grown radishes and red-cooked pork. They transport dozens of empanadas, juggling sheet pans on the G train. They pack boxes of butterscotch cupcakes, Sichuan-spiced beef jerky and grapefruit marmalade. They haul boiled peanuts, ice-grinding machines, sandwich presses and at least one toaster oven painted hot pink. One Saturday
title: Their Future, Made by Hand

body: THOUGH Willie Holmes had been traveling back and forth to New York for a few years, primarily for modeling jobs, he had little knowledge of the city's housing market -- just vague impressions from his New York friends, most of whom lived in Harlem. After six years in the Army, he was ready to relocate to New York, in order to further his modeling
title: THE HUNT; A Home In Brooklyn, On the G.I. Bill

body: Brooklyn is one of the most Democratic counties in the country. The nearly 900,000 enrolled Democrats in the borough outnumber Republicans by about eight to one. More Brooklynites left the party affiliation line on their latest Board of Elections enrollment forms blank than the 112,000 who described themselves as Republicans. Of all the members of
title: MILL BASIN JOURNAL; Brooklyn's G.O.P. Is Old Enough, but Quite a Few Members Shy of Grand

body: For generations, the islands of Jamaica Bay, the 26-square-mile natural sanctuary off the Brooklyn and Queens shoreline that is home to hundreds of species of migratory birds and marine life, have been disappearing, victims of environmental neglect. A combination of factors, including development encroaching into the bay and erosion caused by the
title: From New York Harbor's Depths, Muck to Restore Islands in Jamaica Bay

body: It was once an unspoken social compact -- move to the right school zone and your child was guaranteed a spot in the right school. But for the second year in a row, hundreds of families throughout the city will receive letters telling them that their children have been placed on a waiting list for their local elementary school. The lists are longer
title: At Some Neighborhood Schools, Waiting Lists Get Longer

body: A divided group of New York State Conservative Party leaders voted Saturday to throw the party's support behind Rick A. Lazio, giving the former congressman's troubled campaign for governor a boost as it struggles to hang on to Republican support. The 14-5 vote, while not binding, strengthens Mr. Lazio's position as he fights off a challenge from
title: Conservative Party Leaders Back Lazio

body: On a good day, the unpleasant byproducts of human existence simply flow tepidly beneath their noses. On lesser days, unmentionable objects block the huge grates in the sewer channels. The workers descend knee deep into the muck and scrape at the dripping clogs. The gunk drips to their shoulders and splashes on their faces, working its way into
title: It's the Stagnant Pay, Not the Stench, That Upsets Sewage Workers in the City

body: WHEN the world was young, there was a phenomenon loosely referred to as the Magical World of Television. Pains were taken to dazzle the eye. Chandeliers appeared extra-prismatic, with mescaline auras. Both the emotions and the visual worlds of those half-hours were bluntly oversaturated and colorized; television's unspoken mandate seemed to be the
title: CRITICAL SHOPPER | ALEXIS BITTAR; Champagne Bubbles Are Extra

body: Encouraged by state and national Republican Party leaders, Dan Senor, an author, private equity executive and Defense Department adviser in the last Bush administration, is seriously considering a political challenge against Senator Kirsten E. Gillibrand, according to three people told of the discussions. Mr. Senor, 38, who is married to the CNN
title: Another Republican Is Encouraged to Join the Race for Senate

body: A sport utility vehicle suddenly accelerated while backing up in a church parking lot in Brooklyn on Sunday afternoon, killing a woman and injuring four other people, including two children, the authorities said. The accident occurred at the Pyeong Ahn Presbyterian Church at 2407 McDonald Avenue in Gravesend about 2:45 p.m. The vehicle, a black
title: S.U.V. Hits 5, Killing One, in Church Parking Lot

body: Who could resist such an invitation? The city street is dark and deserted. The buildings are empty. There are no witnesses. A lone man carrying a briefcase, after a long day at the office perhaps, approaches a subway staircase. Out of the subterranean gloom, a giant human hand protrudes, its index finger beckoning the office worker, inviting him
title: EXHIBITION REVIEW | 'CHARLES ADDAMS'S NEW YORK'; The Perverse Pleasures Underneath The Ordinary

body: It's only a story. It's only a story. It's only. . . . But the sense of immediacy Mark Mills brings to THE INFORMATION OFFICER (Random House, $25) is so intense that this breathtaking novel reads more like a memoir than a wartime thriller. It's May 1942 on the Mediterranean island of Malta, pounded by Axis forces because it's ''the lone Allied
title: CRIME; Devil's Island

author: Pete Hamill, the author of more than 20 books, is a distinguished writer in residence at the Arthur L. Carter Journalism Institute at New York University.
body: WILLIE MAYS The Life, the Legend By James S. Hirsch Illustrated. 628 pp. Scribner. $30 A long time ago in America, there was a beautiful game called baseball. This was before 30 major-league teams were scattered in a blurry variety of divisions; before 162-game seasons and extended playoffs and fans who watched World Series games in thick down
title: Say Hey

body: In New York's cold-case crime files, few have as firm a grip on the collective psyche of city law enforcement officers as the so-called zip-gun bomber. ''Here is a case that has so many turns, and it's still unsolved,'' said one law enforcement official who is familiar with it. ''Some of the people involved are still here, some are deceased. It is
title: 'New Developments' in Case of a Killer-by-Mail Who Last Struck in '96

body: SATURDAY night in the neighborhood that once gave America fever, a Brooklyn that looks to itself for employment and has little time for the glittering island to the north. A bridge rises out of it, a silver ramp, and you can see ocean beneath it, darkness running all the way to Portugal, and from there down the Mediterranean to the Middle East.
title: RESTAURANT REVIEW; South of the Moon, North of the Sea

body: One River Place blends easily into the dense forest of Manhattan skyscrapers, its vanity address camouflaging its precise location. Still, even in New York City, a 40-story tower containing 900 apartments should be difficult to miss. But the Census Bureau did. The apartment building at 500 12th Avenue, between 41st and 42nd Streets, was one of the
title: For the Census, Knowing Where to Look In New York Is Half the Battle

body: TAMMANY--Joan (nee Shannahan). Lifelong New Yorker, died February 8, 2010. Faithful parishioner at Our Lady of Angels R.C. Church in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn. Taught 36 years in New York City public elementary schools. Graduate of Notre Dame College and St. John's University. Beloved wife of the late James Francis Tammany. Loving daughter of the late
title: Paid Notice: Deaths TAMMANY, JOAN (NEE SHANNAHAN)

author: E-mail: citycritic@nytimes.com
body: Jean Ryan is the kind of New Yorker who makes everyone else feel lazy. She has two master's degrees and a black belt in tae kwon do. She serves on her local community board. You know the type? Try this one: When she had eye surgery two weeks ago, she refused sedation. She and her husband moved to Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, in 1972, counting on the R
title: CITY | CRITIC; A Godsend, Except When It's Not

body: Recurring Themes Throughout the month at City Bakery, 3 West 18th Street, there are dozens of variations on a hot chocolate theme, with a different featured flavor each day, $2 to $5.50, marshmallow 50 cents more. On Feb. 3, it's Chinese cinnamon: (212) 366-1414, thecitybakery.com. A roster of cheese fondues, including one made with Sardinian
title: Calendar

body: Opening this Week FAUSTINA Scott Conant's makeover of Table 8 is to open on Feb. 5. Antipasti, raw bar items, cured meats and pastas dominate the mostly Italian menu: Cooper Square Hotel, 25 Cooper Square (East Fifth Street), (212) 475-3400. FIVE NAPKIN BURGER An uptown branch of this Ninth Avenue restaurant has moved into the former Ollie's space.
title: Off the Menu

body: FILER--William B. Devoted husband of the late Santina, loving father of Mary and husband Neil and adored grandpop of Cara and Matt. 12:00 Mass on February 6, St. Andrews, 6713 Ridge Blvd., Brooklyn. In lieu of flowers, send donations to Bay Ridge Center Meals-on-Wheels or TDF/ Theater Access Project.
title: Paid Notice: Deaths FILER, WILLIAM B

body: INSIDE the Bay Ridge Manor catering hall in Brooklyn recently, preparations were under way for yet another rites-of-passage weekend: bar mitzvahs, weddings, sweet 16s. But in an upstairs office resembling a military headquarters a different kind of promise was being fulfilled: '' 'White Irish Drinkers'!,'' a young woman said, answering the phone.
title: FILM; Going Really Indie, With His Own Cash

body: Tom Townsend pulled a quarter from his coat pocket. It was no ordinary quarter: He usually keeps it and another one just like it in a plastic case at home, and as he held the rusty-brown 1996 coin in his hand at a funeral home in Brooklyn on Thursday night, people gathered around and stared at it and touched it, tracing their fingers over its
title: Men Who Once Bent Steel Are Now on Bended Knee

body: Joe Rollino once lifted 475 pounds. He used neither his arms nor his legs but, reportedly, his teeth. With just one finger he raised up 635 pounds; with his back he moved 3,200. He bit down on quarters to bend them with his thumb. People called him the Great Joe Rollino, the Mighty Joe Rollino and even the World's Strongest Man, and what did it
title: At a Mighty 104, Gone While Still Going Strong

body: $2.6 MILLION 364-370 Bay Ridge Parkway (between Third and Fourth Avenues) Bay Ridge, Brooklyn A doctor has bought this vacant one-story 7,500-square-foot medical building with eight suites for his medical practice. It also has outdoor parking. Buyer: 370 Bay Ridge Parkway L.L.C. Seller: Pipitsa Vassilopoulou Brokers: Matthew Giordano and Stephen P.

body: Bill de Blasio, New York City's new public advocate, is a lifelong Democrat and a likely future mayoral contender. But ask him to name the most innovative political force in the state, and he points to the Working Families Party. ''On the issues they care about, from minimum wage to tenant issues to development, they are absolutely definitional --
title: As Clout Grows, Working Families Party Faces a Question: Has It Reached Too Far?

body: With the number of visitors to New York City declining by almost 2 million last year, it might be reasonable to expect that Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg would offer a less than rosy view of the decline, or at least express some concern that a continued slump might be in store in 2010. But at a news conference on Monday, the mayor was having none of
title: Mayor Sticking by Tourism Projections Despite Dropoff in 2009

body: Laura saved Anthony. They first met in 1993, when she was 20 and he was 34 and they were both in recovery programs, undergoing treatment for mental illness. He was shuttling between home and inpatient psychiatric units and spotted Laura at a day clinic. ''I felt like I always knew her,'' he said. Back then, she had a crush on someone else. Thirteen
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Engaged, Employed and Wrestling With Mental Illness
